description.narrative: Philippine Safe Abortion Advocacy Network (Pinsan) through Women’s Global Network for Reproductive Rights (WGNRR) has been awarded a contribution by the State of the Netherlands, represented by the Minister for Foreign Trade and Development Cooperation for the activity 3D: Decriminalize, Destigmatize and Demystify abortion in the Philippines.

The Philippines is one of a handful of countries which criminalize abortion without clear exceptions on any grounds, not even allowing the procedure to save the life or protect the health of a pregnant woman, when pregnancy is a result of rape or incest, or in cases of serious foetal deformity. Whilst prosecutions are rare, these criminal provisions and the stigma associated with abortion forces women to resort to unsafe and clandestine procedures. An estimated number of 610,000 abortions per year and over 100,000 Filipino women hospitalized due to complications. Three women die every day due to unsafe abortion complications.
Thirteen percent of women who have had an abortion in the Philippines cite pregnancy as a result of rape as their reason for seeking an abortion . One woman is raped every 71 minutes according to the 2014 Philippine National Police statistics. The absolute criminal ban on abortion violates women’s fundamental human rights, including the right to life, health, nondiscrimination, privacy, and freedom from cruel, inhuman, and degrading treatment. Furthermore despite adoption in 2013 of the Responsible Parenthood and Reproductive Health Law stating that every individual has the right to humane, compassionate, nonjudgmental, post abortion care, a significant number of women approaching medical facilities after an abortion still experience abuse, discrimination and multiple types of delay in receiving care. Women are often denied services, and some are arrested and threatened with imprisonment. Fear of criminalisation and abortion stigma are major factors in preventing women seeking medical help following complications from unsafe abortion.

The main purposes of the activity are: 1. To strengthen the network and mobilize communities for sustainable abortion advocacy and campaigning. 2. To research and publish about the lived realities of women and their communities on abortion. 3. To conduct sustained campaigning to end unsafe abortion. 4. To popularize the new Administrative Order on Prevention and Management of Abortion and its Complications (PMAC). 5. To advance reforms in the penal and legal provisions on abortion. 6. To provide accurate and scientific data about abortion. 7. To create international engagements for sustainable abortion advocacy and campaigning in the Philippines. 8. To carry out a judicial review on violations and abuses in the context of post-abortion care.
This project targets women and girls, community-based organisations, traditional media, health service providers, human rights advocates, legislators and the general public.
